subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] QS-SAMPA: a proposed format for plain-text Quickscript
msgSnippet: ... But what happens when you are not at your own computer, which happens quite a bit to me? Then you can t rely on the special keyboard layout you created.
messageBody:
Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
>
>
> Hi Moira,
>
> There are two separate issues here:
> 1) A standard ASCII representation of QS would (a) facilitate online
> discussion and (b) provide an easy way to exchange QS documents in
> plain text.
> 2) Any individual can create a personal keyboard layout to optimize
> typing effort and/or mnemonic functions of key assignments. (For
> example, I greatly increased my typing speed when I switched from the
> Qwerty to the Dvorak keyboard layout. It took a few months to reach
> full speed, but it was well worth it.)
>

But what happens when you are not at your own computer, which happens
quite a bit to me? Then you can't rely on the special keyboard layout
you created. Plus, creating keyboard layouts sounds like a big pain in
the butt. Every time I installed a new system, I'd have to install the
new keyboard layout before I could type QS, and using different keyboard
layouts for different platforms might further complicate things to the
point of wanting to smash a few keys. And I assume I'd have to switch
between layouts for when I wanted to type QS and when I wanted to type
TO. For better or worse, we are going to be stuck to this new standard,
so we should make sure it makes sense for all users, not just those who
are comfortable with SAMPA.

I also hope we are not loosing sight of QS. We should be able to think
and write in QS directly. If we are going to spend so much of our time
looking at the ASCII representations of QS, I wonder if we haven't
defeated ourselves.

Paul
